qna.a: Located on the Ground Floor, this room has been used since 1917 as exhibition space for White House ceramics, glass, and silver. The painting of First Lady Grace Coolidge has hung in the China Room since 1952.
q: Let's go to the China Room
Take me to the China Room

qna.a: Many presidents have used the Resolute Sofa in the Oval Office. It was made from the timbers of HMS Resolute, an abandoned British ship discovered by an American vessel and returned to the Queen of England. When the ship was retired, Queen Victoria commissioned the Sofa and presented to President Rutherford Hayes in 1880.

The Green Room, the first of the State Rooms to be named for the color of its textiles, is furnished in the late Federal style popular when the White House was first occupied. 

The least formal of the state parlors, the Green Room provides a serene setting for small gatherings, interviews, teas, and social activities.
q: Let's go to the Green Room
Take me to the Green Room

qna.a:
Thank You for visiting the Whitehouse, we have reached the end of your tour. Feel free to retake the tour or take another one. 
 Available tours include the Color Tour and the Regular Tour
The Regular Tour will take you through the China Room, State Dining Room,Library, Vermeil Room, and the Oval Office, enjoy!

The Vermeil Room, located on the Ground Floor of the Executive Mansion, houses the extensive collection of vermeil, or gilded silver, that was bequeathed by Margaret Thompson Biddle to the White House in 1957. First Lady Mamie Eisenhower was the first to display the newly acquired vermeil collection in the room and today the room also displays several portraits of first ladies of the twentieth century.
q: Let's go to the Vermeil Room

The Red Room was the last of the state parlors to be named for a color, boldly decorated with red fabrics first in 1845, by James K. Polk. Today the furnishings are in the American "Empire" or
"Grecian" style that was popular in the early nineteenth century.
q: Let's go to the Red Room
Take me to the Red Room

qna.a: This Grecian style sofa with gilded and scrolled arms and feet was made by an unknown New York cabinetmaker influenced by English Regency and French Empire forms. The sofa became part of the White House Collection in 1961.

Americans have developed a sentimental attachment to the Oval Office. Television broadcasts from the Oval Office, such as President Reagan's speech following the Challenger explosion, have left a lasting impressions in the minds of Americans.
q: Let's go to the Oval Office
Take me to the Oval Office

qna.a: We are not currently in a quiz or leaving feedback

The blue and gold silk used for the walls and the curtains were added in 1952 and the chairs are part of the Bellangé suite. The Blue Room is located on the State Floor of the Executive Mansion. The oval parlor has been known as Blue Room since Martin Van Buren’s 1837 redecoration. The room is often used for receptions, photo opportunities, and during the holiday season is home to the official White House Christmas Tree.
q: Let's go to the Blue Room

Welcome to the White House! Feel free to take the Color Tour or Regular Tour.

The State Dining Room, the second largest room in the White House, is the setting for State Dinners, when a head of state is entertained, as well as for
"official dinners," when the guest of honor is prime minister, ambassador, or
private citizen.
q: Let's go to the State Dining Room
Show me the State Dining Room
Take me to the State Dining Room

qna.a: The Library is located on the Ground Floor of the White House. Although libraries have been a mainstay in the White House since the Millard Fillmore administration, it was not until 1935 that President Franklin D. Roosevelt formally designated a room for the library. The Library boasts thousands of books and the room occasionally serves as the backdrop for meetings, interviews, or televised speeches.
